title: 1411-E
statement: E. Poman Numberstime limit per test1 secondmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputYou've got a string $$$S$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ lowercase English letters from your friend. It turned out that this is a number written inpomannumerals. The poman numeral system is long forgotten. All that's left is the algorithm to transform number from poman numerals to the numeral system familiar to us. Characters of $$$S$$$ are numbered from $$$1$$$ to $$$n$$$ from left to right. Let's denote the value of $$$S$$$ as $$$f(S)$$$, it is defined as follows:If $$$|S| > 1$$$, an arbitrary integer $$$m$$$ ($$$1 \\le m < |S|$$$) is chosen, and it is defined that $$$f(S) = -f(S[1, m]) + f(S[m + 1, |S|])$$$, where $$$S[l, r]$$$ denotes the substring of $$$S$$$ from the $$$l$$$-th to the $$$r$$$-th position, inclusively.Otherwise $$$S = c$$$, where $$$c$$$ is some English letter. Then $$$f(S) = 2^{pos(c)}$$$, where $$$pos(c)$$$ is the position of letter $$$c$$$ in the alphabet ($$$pos($$$a$$$) = 0$$$, $$$pos($$$z$$$) = 25$$$).Note that $$$m$$$ is chosen independently on each step.Your friend thinks it is possible to get $$$f(S) = T$$$ by choosing the right $$$m$$$ on every step. Is he right?InputThe first line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$T$$$ ($$$2 \\leq n \\leq 10^5$$$, $$$-10^{15} \\leq T \\leq 10^{15}$$$).The second line contains a string $$$S$$$ consisting of $$$n$$$ lowercase English letters.OutputPrint "Yes" if it is possible to get the desired value. Otherwise, print "No".You can print each letter in any case (upper or lower).ExamplesInput2 -1 baOutputYesInput3 -7 abcOutputNoInput7 -475391 qohshraOutputYesNoteIn the second example, you cannot get $$$-7$$$. But you can get $$$1$$$, for example, as follows:First choose $$$m = 1$$$, then $$$f($$$abc$$$) = -f($$$a$$$) + f($$$bc$$$)$$$$$$f($$$a$$$) = 2^0 = 1$$$$$$f($$$bc$$$) = -f($$$b$$$) + f($$$c$$$) = -2^1 + 2^2 = 2$$$In the end $$$f($$$abc$$$) = -1 + 2 = 1$$$

processed.result:
You are given a string $S$ consisting of lowercase English letters. This string represents a number written in a special numeral system called "poman numerals".  

To convert this number to our familiar decimal system, you follow these rules:

1. **If the string has more than one character:**
   - Choose an integer $m$ where $1 \le m < |S|$ (the length of the string).
   - The value of the string is calculated as:  $-f(S[1, m]) + f(S[m + 1, |S|])$, where $S[l, r]$ represents the substring of $S$ from the $l$-th to the $r$-th character (inclusive).

2. **If the string has only one character:**
   - The value of the string is $2^{pos(c)}$, where $pos(c)$ is the position of the letter $c$ in the alphabet (a=0, b=1, ..., z=25).

Your task is to determine if it's possible to get a specific target value $T$ by choosing the right $m$ at each step of the conversion process.

**Input:**

- The first line contains two integers $n$ (the length of the string) and $T$ (the target value).
- The second line contains the string $S$.

**Output:**

- Print "Yes" if it's possible to get the target value $T$, otherwise print "No".

You are given a string of letters representing a number in a special system.  The value of the number depends on how you split the string into two parts and recursively calculate the value of each part.  You need to determine if it's possible to get a target number by making the right splits.
